questions.subject: History
questions.question: Its collapse was imminent and came within half a century after its second greatest city, the market center Audaghost, fell. The Sanhaja had taken that city, and one of its former constituent people, the Susu, would murder its royal line. It was known as Wagadu by its citizens – a fact related to us in the chronicles of al-Bakri who described its society in detail, including its future major capital at Kumbi Saleh. Situated between the Sahara and the headwaters of the Senegal and Niger Rivers, it became the first great trading empire of western Africa. For 10 points, identify this African kingdom whose name lives on in a west African country.

questions.subject: Geography
questions.question: One of its major southeastern towns is found on the Hyblaei Hills, and much of its agriculture takes place on the Plain of Catania. Madonie Park is a major preserve in its north, and this home to such provinces as Enna and Raguse has such major urban areas as Noto. The autonomous region dominated by this territory also includes Pelagie, Panteleria, Egadi, and Lipari. For 10 points, name this home to Mount Etna and Syracuse, an island found across the Strait of Messina from the city of Reggio on the southwest of the mainland of Italy.

questions.subject: Mythology
questions.question: According to legends, bees formed when this god's tears hit the desert sand. This god once punished humanity by sending the vengeful goddess Sekhmet. The cow-headed fertility goddess Hathor is called the eye of this god. At night, this god turns into a giant cat in order to slay the serpent Apophis or Apep, who attacks this god's boat in the underworld in an attempt to destroy the sun. For 10 points, name this Egyptian sun god, who was eventually combined with Amun.

questions.subject: History
questions.question: This state's eventually successful attempt to mark its border at the Harris Line resulted in a skirmish at Phillips Corners against another territory. This state was represented in Congress during the Civil War by the leader of the Peace Democrats, or Copperheads, Clement Vallandigham. John Filo took a picture in this state of Mary Ann Vecchio kneeling over the body of Jeffrey Miller. That photo in this state came after a National Guard shooting of war protestors at Kent State University. For 10 points, name this state where the Cuyahoga River caught fire in 1969 and whose residents are known as Buckeyes.

questions.subject: Science
questions.question: The study of this subatomic particle's behavior is a significant part of astrochemistry. The 2011 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded for the discovery of neutrino oscillations, which shows that these particles have mass. There are three types of neutrinos: electron neutrinos, muon neutrinos, and tau neutrinos. They are electrically neutral, weakly interacting, and have extremely small, almost negligible, mass. For 10 points, name this elusive fundamental particle that is abundant in the universe.

questions.subject: Literature
questions.question: This novel centers around a magical circus called 'Le Cirque des Rêves' or 'The Circus of Dreams,' which operates only at night. The circus serves as a venue for a magical competition between two young illusionists, Celia Bowen and Marco Alisdair. Unbeknownst to them, the competition is a game set up by their mentors, and only one can be left standing. As the game unfolds, Celia and Marco fall in love, making the competition even more challenging. For 10 points, name this fantasy novel written by Erin Morgenstern.

questions.subject: Literature
questions.question: This classic novel tells the story of a young orphan girl who is mistakenly sent to live with two elderly siblings, Matthew and Marilla Cuthbert, at the fictional Green Gables farm in Prince Edward Island, Canada. The girl, with her red hair and lively imagination, is initially a disappointment to the Cuthberts, who had intended to adopt a boy to help with their farm. However, she wins their hearts and the hearts of readers as she navigates through various adventures and mishaps. For 10 points, name this beloved novel written by Lucy Maud Montgomery.

questions.subject: Geography
questions.question: This river is the longest in the world, stretching over approximately 6,650 kilometers (4,130 miles) from its source in Burundi to its mouth in Egypt, where it empties into the Mediterranean Sea. The river flows through multiple countries, including Rwanda, Uganda, South Sudan, Sudan, and Egypt. It has played a significant role in the history and development of the civilizations that settled along its banks, particularly ancient Egypt. For 10 points, name this iconic river in northeastern Africa.

questions.subject: History
questions.question: This ancient empire was one of the most significant civilizations of the ancient Near East. It was located in the region known as Mesopotamia, between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers, in what is now present-day Iraq and parts of Syria and Turkey. This empire is known for its advancements in writing (using cuneiform script), law (the Code of Hammurabi), and mathematics (the sexagesimal system). It fell to the Persians in 539 BCE. For 10 points, name this ancient empire, often considered the cradle of civilization.

questions.subject: Science
questions.question: This celestial event occurs when the moon moves between the Earth and the sun, obscuring the sun's light and casting a shadow on the Earth. It can only occur during a new moon phase. There are different types of this event, including total, partial, annular, and hybrid eclipses, depending on the alignment of the moon and the sun. During a total this event, the sun is completely blocked, revealing the sun's corona. For 10 points, name this natural phenomenon.

questions.subject: Literature
questions.question: This novel, often considered a bildungsroman or coming-of-age story, follows the life of a young girl named Scout Finch as she grows up in the racially charged Deep South during the 1930s. The novel deals with themes of racial injustice, moral growth, and empathy. Scout's father, Atticus Finch, is a principled lawyer who defends a black man accused of raping a white woman, facing a prejudiced society. For 10 points, name this Pulitzer Prize-winning novel written by Harper Lee.

questions.subject: Geography
questions.question: This mountain range extends over 3,100 kilometers (1,900 miles) across South Asia, covering several countries including India, Nepal, Bhutan, and China (Tibet). It is home to the world's highest peak, Mount Everest, which reaches an elevation of 8,848 meters (29,029 feet) above sea level. This range also contains several other peaks that are among the world's highest. The rivers that originate in this range, such as the Ganges and the Indus, are vital for the region's water supply and agriculture. For 10 points, name this famous mountain range in Asia.

questions.subject: History
questions.question: This ancient civilization emerged in the region around the Yellow River (Huang He) in present-day China. It is one of the world's oldest civilizations, with a history dating back to the Neolithic period. This civilization is known for its advancements in agriculture, including the development of early rice and millet farming techniques. It also created one of the earliest writing systems, using characters on oracle bones and bronze artifacts. For 10 points, name this ancient civilization of China.

questions.subject: Geography
questions.question: This desert is located in southwestern Africa, covering much of Namibia and parts of Angola and South Africa. It is one of the oldest deserts in the world, with a history of arid conditions dating back millions of years. Despite its dryness, it is home to a diverse range of desert-adapted plants and animals, including unique species like the Welwitschia plant and the desert-adapted elephant. It is known for its striking landscapes, including vast sand dunes and rocky desert plains. For 10 points, name this desert in Africa.

questions.subject: History
questions.question: This ancient city was the capital of the powerful Aztec Empire, situated on an island in Lake Texcoco in present-day Mexico City. The city was founded in 1325 and became a major cultural, religious, and political center in Mesoamerica. It was known for its impressive architecture, including the grand pyramid-shaped temple known as the Templo Mayor. The city was conquered and destroyed by Spanish conquistadors led by Hernán Cortés in 1521. For 10 points, name this once-great city of the Aztecs.

questions.subject: Science
questions.question: This fundamental force of nature is responsible for holding the components of an atomic nucleus together. It is one of the four fundamental forces in the universe, along with gravity, electromagnetism, and the weak force. The exchange of particles called gluons mediates this force. It is a strong force that overcomes the electromagnetic repulsion between positively charged protons in the nucleus. For 10 points, name this force that binds quarks and neutrons together.

questions.subject: Literature
questions.question: This dystopian novel is set in the totalitarian society of Gilead, a theocratic regime that has replaced the United States. The story is narrated by a handmaid named Offred, who is assigned to a high-ranking commander for the purpose of bearing a child. In this society, handmaids are stripped of their names and identities and must conform to strict rules. The novel explores themes of power, gender, and freedom. For 10 points, name this novel written by Margaret Atwood.

questions.subject: History
questions.question: This ancient civilization emerged in the valley of the Tigris and Euphrates rivers, in what is now present-day Iraq and parts of Kuwait and Syria. It is one of the earliest known civilizations and is credited with the invention of writing (using cuneiform script) and the wheel. The Babylonian and Assyrian empires were prominent in this region. Its decline was linked to environmental factors and invasions by neighboring peoples. For 10 points, name this ancient civilization.

questions.subject: Science
questions.question: This unit of measure is used to express the amount of energy or work done. It is defined as the energy required to apply a force of one newton over a distance of one meter in the direction of the force. This unit is named after the scientist who helped formulate the laws of motion and universal gravitation. It is a derived unit in the International System of Units (SI). For 10 points, name this unit of energy and work.

questions.subject: Literature
questions.question: This epic poem, composed by an anonymous poet, is one of the most important works of Old English literature. It tells the story of a hero named Beowulf, who comes to the aid of the Danish king Hrothgar to defeat the monstrous Grendel and later, Grendel's mother. Beowulf then becomes king of the Geats and faces a dragon in battle, ultimately sacrificing his life to save his people. For 10 points, name this epic poem set in Scandinavia.

questions.subject: Geography
questions.question: This mountain range runs along the western coast of South America, stretching over 7,000 kilometers (4,300 miles) from Venezuela to Chile and Argentina. It is the world's longest continental mountain range. The highest peak in this range is Aconcagua, reaching an elevation of 6,960.8 meters (22,837 feet) above sea level. It is known for its rich biodiversity, containing numerous unique and diverse ecosystems. For 10 points, name this famous mountain range in South America.

questions.subject: Science
questions.question: This chemical element has the symbol 'Na' and atomic number 11. It is a highly reactive metal, and its name is derived from the Latin word 'natrium.' This element is essential for various biological processes and is found in table salt, sodium chloride. It is also used in various industrial applications, including the production of chemicals and soaps. When combined with chlorine, it forms common table salt. For 10 points, name this alkali metal with a silvery-white appearance.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This process occurs in the mitochondria and involves the oxidation of pyruvate molecules to produce carbon dioxide, NADH, FADH2, and ATP. For 10 points, name this central metabolic pathway.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This physical quantity represents the product of an object's mass and its velocity. In a closed system, this quantity is conserved. For 10 points, name this fundamental concept in physics.

questions.subject: IB Analysis and Approaches
questions.question: This theorem states that any continuous function on a closed interval [a, b] is uniformly continuous on that interval. For 10 points, name this theorem named after a German mathematician.

questions.subject: IB History of the Americas
questions.question: This treaty, signed in 1848, ended the Mexican-American War and ceded a large portion of Mexico's territory to the United States, including present-day California, Arizona, New Mexico, and parts of Utah, Nevada, and Colorado. For 10 points, name this treaty.

questions.subject: IB Chemistry
questions.question: This law states that the rate of a chemical reaction is directly proportional to the product of the concentrations of the reactants. For 10 points, name this law named after a French chemist.

questions.subject: IB Economics
questions.question: This economic concept describes a situation where the production of one good increases as the production of another good decreases. For 10 points, name this phenomenon.

questions.subject: IB English Literature
questions.question: This novel, published in 1847, tells the story of a young governess who is hired to educate the daughter of a wealthy man named Mr. Rochester. For 10 points, name this classic novel by Charlotte Bronte.

questions.subject: IB Visual Arts
questions.question: This Dutch artist is known for his works such as 'The Starry Night' and 'Sunflowers.' For 10 points, name this post-impressionist painter.

questions.subject: IB Mathematics: Applications and Interpretation
questions.question: This mathematical concept is used to represent the chance of an event occurring, expressed as a value between 0 and 1. For 10 points, name this probability measure.

questions.subject: IB Theatre
questions.question: This Greek playwright is known for his tragedies, including 'Oedipus Rex' and 'Antigone.' For 10 points, name this ancient playwright.

questions.subject: IB Environmental Systems and Societies
questions.question: This biome is characterized by cold temperatures, low biodiversity, and a layer of permanently frozen soil known as permafrost. For 10 points, name this biome.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This data structure consists of nodes connected in a hierarchical manner. Each node has a parent and zero or more children. For 10 points, name this data structure.

questions.subject: IB Business Management
questions.question: This management theory emphasizes the importance of dividing labor into specialized tasks to increase efficiency. For 10 points, name this management theory named after its founder.

questions.subject: IB Psychology
questions.question: This psychological disorder is characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and loss of interest in activities. For 10 points, name this mood disorder.

questions.subject: IB Design Technology
questions.question: This manufacturing process involves the use of a computer-controlled machine to carve out three-dimensional objects from a solid block of material. For 10 points, name this process.

questions.subject: IB Music
questions.question: This composer, known for his compositions such as 'Symphony No. 9' and 'Ode to Joy,' is considered one of the greatest composers of all time. For 10 points, name this German composer.

questions.subject: IB Film
questions.question: This director is known for films such as 'Pulp Fiction,' 'Kill Bill,' and 'Inglourious Basterds.' For 10 points, name this American filmmaker.

questions.subject: IB World Religions
questions.question: This religion, founded by Siddhartha Gautama, teaches the Four Noble Truths and the Eightfold Path. For 10 points, name this major world religion.

questions.subject: IB Spanish
questions.question: This Spanish artist, known for his surrealist paintings such as 'The Persistence of Memory,' was born in Figueres, Catalonia. For 10 points, name this artist.

questions.subject: IB French
questions.question: This French writer is known for novels such as 'Les Misérables' and 'The Hunchback of Notre-Dame.' For 10 points, name this author.

questions.subject: IB Mandarin
questions.question: This Chinese philosopher, also known as Kongzi, is the central figure in Confucianism. For 10 points, name this philosopher.

questions.subject: IB Arabic
questions.question: This influential Islamic scholar is known for his comprehensive collection of hadiths, which are sayings and actions of the Prophet Muhammad. For 10 points, name this scholar.

questions.subject: IB Russian
questions.question: This Russian author is known for novels such as 'War and Peace' and 'Anna Karenina.' For 10 points, name this prolific writer.

questions.subject: IB Dutch
questions.question: This Dutch artist is known for his works such as 'The Night Watch' and 'The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp.' For 10 points, name this Dutch painter.

questions.subject: IB German
questions.question: This German composer is known for his compositions such as 'Symphony No. 5' and 'Für Elise.' For 10 points, name this classical composer.

questions.subject: IB Italian
questions.question: This Italian artist is known for his works such as 'David' and 'The Creation of Adam.' For 10 points, name this Renaissance artist.

questions.subject: IB Japanese
questions.question: This Japanese filmmaker is known for his films such as 'Seven Samurai' and 'Rashomon.' For 10 points, name this legendary director.

questions.subject: IB Latin
questions.question: This Roman poet is known for his epic poem 'The Aeneid.' For 10 points, name this ancient poet.

questions.subject: IB Classical Greek
questions.question: This ancient Greek philosopher is known for his dialogues such as 'The Republic' and 'Apology.' For 10 points, name this philosopher.

questions.subject: IB Mandarin B
questions.question: This Chinese dynasty, known for its contributions to art, literature, and philosophy, ruled from 1368 to 1644. For 10 points, name this dynasty.

questions.subject: IB Spanish B
questions.question: This Spanish artist, known for his surrealist paintings such as 'The Persistence of Memory,' was born in Figueres, Catalonia. For 10 points, name this artist.

questions.subject: IB French B
questions.question: This French artist, known for his impressionist paintings such as 'Impression, Sunrise,' is often regarded as the founder of impressionism. For 10 points, name this artist.

questions.subject: IB Italian B
questions.question: This Italian sculptor and architect is known for his works such as 'David' and 'Pieta.' For 10 points, name this Renaissance artist.

questions.subject: IB Japanese B
questions.question: This Japanese novelist is known for his works such as 'Norwegian Wood' and 'Kafka on the Shore.' For 10 points, name this contemporary author.

questions.subject: IB Latin B
questions.question: This Roman statesman and orator is known for his speeches against the dictator Julius Caesar. For 10 points, name this Roman politician.

questions.subject: IB Classical Greek B
questions.question: This ancient Greek playwright is known for his tragedies such as 'Oedipus Rex' and 'Antigone.' For 10 points, name this playwright.

questions.subject: IB Mandarin Ab Initio
questions.question: This Chinese philosopher, also known as Kongzi, is the central figure in Confucianism. For 10 points, name this philosopher.

questions.subject: IB Spanish Ab Initio
questions.question: This Spanish artist, known for his surrealist paintings such as 'The Persistence of Memory,' was born in Figueres, Catalonia. For 10 points, name this artist.

questions.subject: IB French Ab Initio
questions.question: This French artist, known for his impressionist paintings such as 'Impression, Sunrise,' is often regarded as the founder of impressionism. For 10 points, name this artist.

questions.subject: IB Italian Ab Initio
questions.question: This Italian sculptor and architect is known for his works such as 'David' and 'Pieta.' For 10 points, name this Renaissance artist.

questions.subject: IB Japanese Ab Initio
questions.question: This Japanese novelist is known for his works such as 'Norwegian Wood' and 'Kafka on the Shore.' For 10 points, name this contemporary author.

questions.subject: IB Latin Ab Initio
questions.question: This Roman statesman and orator is known for his speeches against the dictator Julius Caesar. For 10 points, name this Roman politician.

questions.subject: IB Classical Greek Ab Initio
questions.question: This ancient Greek playwright is known for his tragedies such as 'Oedipus Rex' and 'Antigone.' For 10 points, name this playwright.

questions.subject: IB Arabic Ab Initio
questions.question: This influential Islamic scholar is known for his comprehensive collection of hadiths, which are sayings and actions of the Prophet Muhammad. For 10 points, name this scholar.

questions.subject: IB Russian Ab Initio
questions.question: This Russian author is known for novels such as 'War and Peace' and 'Anna Karenina.' For 10 points, name this prolific writer.

questions.subject: IB Dutch Ab Initio
questions.question: This Dutch artist is known for his works such as 'The Night Watch' and 'The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp.' For 10 points, name this Dutch painter.

questions.subject: IB German Ab Initio
questions.question: This German composer is known for his compositions such as 'Symphony No. 5' and 'Für Elise.' For 10 points, name this classical composer.

questions.subject: IB Chinese Ab Initio
questions.question: This Chinese dynasty, known for its contributions to art, literature, and philosophy, ruled from 1368 to 1644. For 10 points, name this dynasty.

questions.subject: Geography
questions.question: One of its major southeastern towns is found on the Hyblaei Hills, and much of its agriculture takes place on the Plain of Catania. Madonie Park is a major preserve in its north, and this home to such provinces as Enna and Raguse has such major urban areas as Noto. The autonomous region dominated by this territory also includes Pelagie, Panteleria, Egadi, and Lipari. For 10 points, name this home to Mount Etna and Syracuse, an island found across the Strait of Messina from the city of Reggio on the southwest of the mainland of Italy.

questions.subject: IB Mathematics
questions.question: This theorem states that any continuous function on a closed interval [a, b] is uniformly continuous on that interval. For 10 points, name this theorem named after a German mathematician.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This physical quantity represents the product of an object's mass and its velocity. In a closed system, this quantity is conserved. For 10 points, name this fundamental concept in physics.

questions.subject: IB Psychology
questions.question: According to this theory of emotion, physiological arousal and the experience of emotion occur simultaneously, each triggering the other. This theory contrasts with the James-Lange theory. For 10 points, name this theory named after two psychologists.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This process occurs in the mitochondria and involves the oxidation of pyruvate molecules to produce carbon dioxide, NADH, FADH2, and ATP. For 10 points, name this central metabolic pathway.

questions.subject: IB History of the Americas
questions.question: This treaty, signed in 1848, ended the Mexican-American War and ceded a large portion of Mexico's territory to the United States, including present-day California, Arizona, New Mexico, and parts of Utah, Nevada, and Colorado. For 10 points, name this treaty.

questions.subject: IB Mathematics
questions.question: This mathematical constant, often denoted by the letter 'e', is approximately equal to 2.71828. It is the base of the natural logarithm and appears in many areas of mathematics, including calculus and probability theory. For 10 points, name this important constant.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This fundamental force is responsible for holding the nucleus of an atom together. It is mediated by particles called gluons. For 10 points, name this force.

questions.subject: IB Psychology
questions.question: This psychological perspective emphasizes the role of unconscious conflicts and early childhood experiences in shaping behavior and personality. It was founded by Sigmund Freud. For 10 points, name this perspective.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This organelle is responsible for the synthesis of proteins in eukaryotic cells. It consists of two subunits, one large and one small, and is composed of RNA and protein. For 10 points, name this cellular structure.

questions.subject: IB History of the Americas
questions.question: This movement, which began in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, advocated for the rights of workers and sought to improve working conditions and wages. It led to the formation of labor unions and the enactment of labor laws. For 10 points, name this social and political movement.

questions.subject: IB Mathematics
questions.question: This theorem, named after a French mathematician, states that if a function is continuous on a closed interval and differentiable on the open interval, then there exists at least one point in the open interval where the derivative of the function is equal to the average rate of change of the function over the closed interval. For 10 points, name this theorem.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This physical principle states that the total energy of an isolated system remains constant over time, regardless of internal changes. For 10 points, name this principle.

questions.subject: IB Psychology
questions.question: This theory, proposed by Albert Bandura, emphasizes the role of observational learning and cognitive processes in shaping behavior. It suggests that individuals can learn new behaviors by observing others and that reinforcement and punishment are not always necessary for learning to occur. For 10 points, name this theory.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This process, which occurs during cell division, ensures that each daughter cell receives an identical set of chromosomes. It involves the separation of sister chromatids. For 10 points, name this phase of mitosis.

questions.subject: IB History of the Americas
questions.question: This landmark Supreme Court case, decided in 1954, declared state laws establishing separate public schools for black and white students to be unconstitutional. It overturned the doctrine of 'separate but equal' established by the Plessy v. Ferguson decision. For 10 points, name this case.

questions.subject: History
questions.question: This medieval conflict, which lasted from 1337 to 1453, was fought between the Kingdom of England and the Kingdom of France over control of the French throne. It is often considered one of the most significant conflicts in European history. For 10 points, name this series of wars.

questions.subject: Geography
questions.question: This country, located in Southeast Asia, is known for its thousands of islands, including Java, Sumatra, Borneo, and Sulawesi. It is the world's largest island country by area and fourth-most populous country. For 10 points, name this country.

questions.subject: IB Mathematics
questions.question: This mathematical function, denoted by f prime of x or dy over dx, represents the rate of change of a function with respect to its independent variable. For 10 points, name this important concept in calculus.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This law states that the pressure of a gas is inversely proportional to its volume at constant temperature. For 10 points, name this law named after a French chemist.

questions.subject: IB Psychology
questions.question: This cognitive bias refers to the tendency to rely on information that is readily available, rather than considering all relevant information when making judgments. For 10 points, name this bias.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This type of cellular transport involves the movement of molecules or ions against their concentration gradient, typically using energy from ATP. For 10 points, name this process.

questions.subject: IB History of the Americas
questions.question: This American president, who served from 1933 to 1945, implemented the New Deal policies to address the Great Depression and led the United States during World War II. For 10 points, name this president.

questions.subject: IB Mathematics
questions.question: This geometric shape has all sides of equal length and all angles of equal measure. For 10 points, name this polygon.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This fundamental particle, discovered in 1932 by Carl Anderson, has the same mass as an electron but opposite charge. For 10 points, name this particle.

questions.subject: IB Psychology
questions.question: This psychological perspective focuses on the ways in which people perceive, process, and retrieve information. It examines mental processes such as memory, problem-solving, and decision-making. For 10 points, name this perspective.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This organelle, found in plant cells but not animal cells, is responsible for photosynthesis. It contains chlorophyll and converts light energy into chemical energy. For 10 points, name this cellular structure.

questions.subject: IB History of the Americas
questions.question: This landmark legislation, signed into law in 1964, outlawed discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin. For 10 points, name this civil rights act.

questions.subject: IB Chemistry
questions.question: This law states that the total pressure exerted by a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the partial pressures of each individual gas in the mixture. For 10 points, name this law.

questions.subject: IB Chemistry
questions.question: This type of chemical bond is formed between two atoms when they share one or more pairs of electrons. For 10 points, name this bond.

questions.subject: IB Chemistry
questions.question: This process involves the conversion of a solid directly into a gas without passing through the liquid state. For 10 points, name this process.

questions.subject: IB Chemistry
questions.question: This law, named after a French chemist, states that the mass of the products in a chemical reaction is equal to the mass of the reactants. For 10 points, name this law.

questions.subject: IB Chemistry
questions.question: This branch of chemistry deals with the study of the rates of chemical reactions and the factors that affect them. For 10 points, name this branch of chemistry.

questions.subject: IB Analysis and Approaches
questions.question: This theorem, formulated by a French mathematician in the 17th century, states that if a function is continuous on a closed interval and differentiable on the open interval, then there exists at least one point in the open interval where the derivative of the function is equal to the average rate of change of the function over the closed interval. For 10 points, name this theorem, which is a special case of the Mean Value Theorem.

questions.subject: IB Analysis and Approaches
questions.question: This mathematical concept, often used in calculus, represents the instantaneous rate of change of a function at a specific point. It is defined as the limit of the average rate of change of the function as the interval approaches zero. For 10 points, name this fundamental concept in calculus.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This fundamental law of physics, formulated by Sir Isaac Newton in the 17th century, states that every object persists in its state of rest or uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external force. It provides the foundation for understanding the motion of objects under the influence of forces. For 10 points, name this law.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This physical quantity, commonly represented by the symbol 'F', is defined as the product of an object's mass and its acceleration. It is measured in units of Newtons. For 10 points, name this fundamental concept in physics.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This programming concept involves breaking down a complex problem into smaller, more manageable subproblems, which are then solved individually. It is often used to simplify the design and implementation of algorithms and programs. For 10 points, name this problem-solving approach.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This data structure organizes data in a hierarchical manner, with each node having at most two children. It is commonly used to implement binary search trees and is an essential concept in computer science and programming. For 10 points, name this data structure.

questions.subject: IB Analysis and Approaches
questions.question: This mathematical concept, named after a German mathematician, represents the total area under a curve between two points on a graph. It is often used to find the cumulative effect or total quantity of a changing quantity. For 10 points, name this concept in calculus.

questions.subject: IB Analysis and Approaches
questions.question: This mathematical principle, named after a French philosopher and mathematician, states that the total number of ways to choose a subset of objects from a larger set is given by the binomial coefficient. It is often used in combinatorics and probability theory. For 10 points, name this principle.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This physical quantity, represented by the symbol 'p', is defined as the product of an object's mass and its velocity. It is a vector quantity, meaning it has both magnitude and direction. For 10 points, name this fundamental concept in physics.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This fundamental law of physics, named after a British physicist, states that the force experienced by a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is proportional to the current, the length of the wire, and the strength of the magnetic field. For 10 points, name this law.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This programming paradigm involves organizing code into reusable components called objects, which interact with each other to perform tasks. It promotes modularity, encapsulation, and code reuse. For 10 points, name this programming paradigm.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This data structure, commonly used to implement LIFO (Last In, First Out) behavior, allows elements to be added or removed only from one end. It follows the principle of Last In, First Out. For 10 points, name this data structure.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This programming language, developed by Sun Microsystems, is commonly used for building enterprise-level applications, web services, and mobile apps. It is known for its platform independence and object-oriented features. For 10 points, name this programming language.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This programming language, often used for system programming and embedded systems development, was developed by Dennis Ritchie at Bell Labs in the early 1970s. It is known for its efficiency and low-level control over hardware. For 10 points, name this programming language.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This sorting algorithm, named after a Hungarian-American mathematician, works by repeatedly swapping adjacent elements if they are in the wrong order. It has an average and worst-case time complexity of O(n^2). For 10 points, name this sorting algorithm.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This programming concept involves breaking down a complex problem into smaller, more manageable subproblems, which are then solved individually. It is often used to simplify the design and implementation of algorithms and programs. For 10 points, name this problem-solving approach.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This programming concept, often used in object-oriented programming, refers to the bundling of data and methods that operate on that data into a single unit. It promotes encapsulation and information hiding. For 10 points, name this concept.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This physiological process, often referred to as 'the body's thermostat', helps regulate body temperature by increasing blood flow to the skin and promoting sweating when the body overheats, and by conserving heat through vasoconstriction and shivering when the body is cold. For 10 points, name this process.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This sports psychology concept, named after a Russian physiologist, refers to the state of optimal functioning where an athlete is fully immersed in their activity, characterized by complete absorption, heightened focus, and a distorted sense of time. For 10 points, name this concept.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This sports science principle, often applied in strength training, states that muscles adapt to the specific demands placed upon them. It suggests that to improve performance, training must progressively overload the muscles by increasing the intensity, duration, or frequency of exercise. For 10 points, name this principle.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This sports science concept, often referred to as 'the gas tank of the body', represents the maximum amount of oxygen that an individual can utilize during intense exercise. It is measured in milliliters of oxygen per kilogram of body weight per minute. For 10 points, name this concept.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This cellular organelle, often referred to as the 'powerhouse of the cell', is responsible for generating adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the primary energy currency of the cell, through the process of cellular respiration. For 10 points, name this organelle.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This process, occurring in the chloroplasts of plant cells, converts light energy into chemical energy, producing glucose and oxygen as byproducts. For 10 points, name this process.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This genetic disorder, caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21, is characterized by intellectual disability, developmental delays, distinctive facial features, and other health problems. For 10 points, name this disorder.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This type of cell division, occurring in sexually reproducing organisms, results in the formation of haploid gametes from diploid germ cells. For 10 points, name this process.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This sports science concept, often referred to as 'the point of no return', represents the intensity of exercise beyond which the body can no longer meet the demands for oxygen and anaerobic metabolism predominates. It is often associated with the buildup of lactic acid and the onset of muscle fatigue. For 10 points, name this concept.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This sports science principle, often applied in training programs, states that the physiological adaptations resulting from exercise are specific to the type of activity performed and the muscles involved. It suggests that training should mimic the movements and energy systems used in the athlete's sport. For 10 points, name this principle.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This sports psychology concept, named after a Russian psychologist, refers to the process of mentally rehearsing or visualizing an athletic performance in order to improve skill execution, reduce anxiety, and enhance confidence. For 10 points, name this concept.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This biomechanical principle, often applied in sports technique analysis, states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. It helps explain how forces are generated and transferred during movement. For 10 points, name this principle.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This cellular process, occurring in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, involves the synthesis of RNA from a DNA template. It is the first step in gene expression and plays a crucial role in protein synthesis. For 10 points, name this process.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This cellular structure, found in plant cells but not animal cells, provides structural support and rigidity to the cell, as well as protection and regulation of cell shape. It is composed of cellulose fibers and other polysaccharides. For 10 points, name this structure.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This genetic disorder, caused by a mutation in the CFTR gene, affects the respiratory, digestive, and reproductive systems, leading to thick, sticky mucus buildup in the lungs, pancreas, and other organs. For 10 points, name this disorder.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This process, occurring during cell division, ensures that each daughter cell receives an equal and complete set of chromosomes. It involves the separation of sister chromatids and the formation of two genetically identical daughter cells. For 10 points, name this process.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This biological concept, named after an English naturalist, refers to the process by which organisms with advantageous traits are more likely to survive and reproduce, leading to the gradual change in populations over time. For 10 points, name this concept.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This type of symbiotic relationship, in which both organisms benefit from the association, is exemplified by the relationship between nitrogen-fixing bacteria and leguminous plants. For 10 points, name this type of relationship.
